msItem.textLang: Primitive Irish written in Ogham script

support.note: Coarse red or pink buff-weathering sandstone
support.desc: The stone was inverted for the carving of a cross.

layoutDesc.layout: It has been suggested that there are possible traces of an ogham inscription on the left angle above the first visible letter in the Latin inscription. Any such inscription likely would have read vertically upwards originally and vertically downwards if the stone is displayed with cross-carving at the top-end. Given the current state of the stone this cannot be said with certainty. Redknap and Lewis deem evidence for the presence of any ogham inscription unconvincing while Macalister argues the presence of legible letters (Macalister 1945; Redknap and Lewis 2007, 164). The Latin inscription is in two lines, originally reading vertically downwards. The later addition of a cross-carving on what was originally the bottom-end of the stone has meant the inversion of reading direction of the inscriptions. If displayed with cross-carving at the top-end, the Latin incription reads vertically upwards. The first letters of both the lines are now obscured.

handDesc.handNote: There is no evidence to indicate how the ogham inscription might have been carved, so the execution technique remains unknown. The Latin inscription is punched lightly. The letters in the Latin inscription are widely spaced capitals with light weight. They show possible influence of Rustic written capitals in the dropped horisontal of the L, and the sickle shaped 'handle' of the G. This inscription is formal, compared to the other stone to a son of VENDONI at Clydai, Pembrokeshire (Nash-Williams 1950: no.307), which was rapidly painted on the stone before cutting with ligatured LI, FI and a reversed D (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 164).

origin.origPlace: Defynnog, Brecknockshire (Brycheiniog), Wales 51.939186, -3.565192 National Grid Reference: SN 925 279

history.provenance: First noted in c1853 when built into the external wall face at the south-west corner of the tower immediately below the lower string-course at St Cynog's Church. Huebner did not incorporate ogham into illustration, neither did Westwood in 1876. Macalister 1945 is first mention of ogham.
Set against the west wall inside the porch of St Cynog's Church by the Ministry of Public Building and Works c 1970.

div.p: The potential Ogham inscription has been suggested to consist of the same commemoration as the Latin inscription (Macalister 1945, 318). There is some debate surrounding whether the legible characters are TNL or TQD. Where Macalister suggests the latter, the Welsh corpus suggests the former which fits the interpretation of the Latin inscription better. Macalister suggests that the Ogham inscription has been chipped away and eroded but the Welsh corpus (Redknap and Lewis 2007) questions its validity entirely.

In the Latin inscription, VENDONI may be Irish, but this may also be a Celtic-Latin name Vendonius. Interpretation of the inscription is inhibited by the loss of the first letters in the inscription. The Welsh Corpus favours the restoration of the first line to [B]RVGN- (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 166) which is the preform to OI brón, MW brwyn 'sorrow'. This appears in MW and OW personal names Bruin, Brwyn and Brwyno as well as OB Broin, Broen and OI Brónach. Given the location of the stone in Brycheiniog, it is also worth noting that Englynion y Beddau, CIB: 162 describes a 'Bruin o Bricheinauc'. The rest of the name in the first line is most likely -IATIO which corresponds to the adjectival suffix appearing in Welsh euraid, 'golden'. The phonetic preservation of -IAT- suggests that the name in the first line of the inscription is Welsh, if so the -O is likely a Collequial Latin or Brittonic nominative ending seen elsewhere in Wales. The name on the second line of the inscription, VENDONI, is likely a spelling of the old Celtic name Vindonius. The spelling VEND- 'white' rather than VIND- is typical of Irish Ogham inscriptions but this also occurs in Romano-British sources 164-6.
